data.text:
Susan Ker Weld, better known as Tuesday Weld, had a challenging childhood that could be considered tragic despite receiving little recognition in Hollywood. Unlike other actresses such as Judy Garland, her story is often overlooked.

The pressure she faced during her childhood had a significant impact on her acting career, as she turned down numerous movie roles that would have made her even more famous. As an actress, she was already exposed to industry pressure, but her mother Yosene Balfour Ker pushed her to work even harder from a young age, leaving her with little choice in the matter.

Tuesday WeldBiography & Profile Summary

Are you a fan of classic Hollywood movies and TV shows? Then, you may have heard of Susan Ker Weld, who is more popularly known as Tuesday Weld. She was born in Manhattan, New York, on August 27, 1943, and had a passion for acting from a very young age. In this article, we will dive deep into the life of Tuesday Weld and discover more about her career, awards, net worth, and personal life.

Tuesday Weld Early Life

Tuesday Weld’s father, Lathrop Motley Weld, passed away in 1947, leaving her family drowning in debt. Her mother, Yosene Balfour Ker, who was a life illustrator and artist, had to support the family by enrolling Tuesday in modeling. Her paternal family considered her mother to be a significant burden, but Weld’s mother never gave up and did everything well for her children. Weld had two siblings, David Balfour Weld and Sarah King Weld.

In 1956, Tuesday Weld made her film debut in Alfred Hitchcock’s crime drama “The Wrong Man.” She starred in the film “Rock, Rock, Rock,” which featured singers such as Frankie Lymon, Chuck Berry, and Johnny Brunette. She also appeared on television shows such as Goodyear Playhouse and Backwoods Cinderella. She is best known for her performance in “The Dark at the Top of the Stairs” and supporting roles, such as in 20th Century Fox’s 1958 film “Rally Round the Flag, Boys!”

Tuesday Weld Career

Tuesday Weld rose to fame for her role in “The Five Pennies,” released in 1959, in which she played Danny Kaye’s daughter and was universally admired. Her career continued to flourish, and she won numerous awards for her outstanding performances. She was nominated for a Golden Globe award for best actress in a motion picture drama in 1972 and won the Academy Award for best female supporting actress in 1977. She also received a Cable ACE Award for her performance in a non-theatrical music program.

In 1982, she received an Emmy Award for her performance as an excellent supporting actress in the film “The Winter of Our Discontent.” She won the BAFTA Award for best lead actress for her role in “Once Upon a Time in America.”

Tuesday Weld Movies

Tuesday Weld’s acting career started in the 1950s and lasted until the early 2000s. Over the years, she appeared in more than 70 movies, showcasing her great talent in a variety of roles. Some of her most notable roles include:

Chelsea Walls (2001): In this drama, Weld played the role of Grace, a painter who lives in a rundown hotel with other struggling artists.

Intimate Affairs (2001): This comedy-drama featured Weld as Aunt Mona, a wealthy socialite who hires a private investigator to spy on her family members.

Feeling Minnesota (1996): In this dark comedy, Weld played Nora, the mother of two brothers who are caught up in a love triangle with a woman named Freddie.

Falling Down (1993): In this thriller, Weld played Elizabeth “Beth” Travino, the estranged wife of the main character.

Heartbreak Hotel (1988): Weld starred as Marie Wolfe, a woman who runs away from her abusive husband and ends up staying at a hotel run by Elvis Presley.

Once Upon a Time in America (1984): This epic crime drama featured Weld as Carol, the former girlfriend of the main character, played by Robert De Niro.

Author! Author! (1982): Weld played Alice Detroit, the girlfriend of a struggling playwright who is trying to raise his kids alone.

Thief (1981): In this neo-noir crime film, Weld played Jessie, the love interest of a professional thief.

Serial (1980): Weld played the role of Marcy, the wife of a man who becomes obsessed with a series of serial murders.

Who’ll Stop the Rain (1978): This war drama featured Weld as Marge Converse, a drug-addicted journalist who helps the main character smuggle drugs out of Vietnam.

Looking for Mr. Goodbar (1977): In this drama, Weld played Katherine Dunn, a schoolteacher who has a dark side.

Play It As It Lays (1972): Weld starred as Maria Wyeth, a disenchanted actress who becomes involved with a director.

A Safe Place (1971): In this experimental drama, Weld played Susan, a young woman who is pursued by a mysterious man.

I Walk the Line (1970): In this drama, Weld played Dorothy, the wife of a small-town sheriff who becomes involved with a man who is on the run from the law.

Pretty Poison (1968): Weld starred as Sue Ann Stepanek, a high school cheerleader who becomes involved with a man who is not what he seems.

Lord Love a Duck (1966): In this dark comedy, Weld played Barbara Ann Greene, a high school student who becomes obsessed with fame and fortune.

The Cincinnati Kid (1965): This drama featured Weld as Melba, the girlfriend of the main character, played by Steve McQueen.

I’ll Take Sweden (1965): In this comedy, Weld played JoJo Holcomb, the daughter of a famous author who is sent to Sweden to live with her father.

Tuesday Weld Net Worth

Tuesday Weld’s net worth is estimated to be $6 million as of March 2023. She is known to have first purchased a beach house in Montauk, New York. She later sold her home and relocated to Carbondale, Colorado. In 2018, she relocated to Hollywood Hills and purchased a 1.8 million USD home. She does not appear to be a fan of automobiles or expensive accessories.

Tuesday Weld Husband

Tuesday Weld’s marriage has never been a happy one. On October 23, 1965, she married Claude Harz, a well-known screenwriter. On February 18, 1971, the couple divorced. Natasha, Susan and Claude’s daughter, was born on August 26, 1966.

Tuesday Weld has set a good example for young people in terms of living their lives. She enrolled in modeling and acting classes because she had a strong desire to make it her career. She teaches us that with tremendous dedication and hard work, we can achieve anything we want in life. Weld has left an indelible mark in the film industry, and her contribution to the world of acting will always be remembered.
